form.longName: PhenX PX031402 - Substances Lifetime Abuse And Dependence
form.preferredDefinition: Respondents answer questions from the National Epidemiologic Survey on Alcohol and Related Conditions-III (NESARC-III) related to their lifetime use of illicit and prescribed substances.

question.questionText: In your entire life, Did you EVER find that your usual amount of a medicine or drug had much less effect on you than it once did? (substances_lifetime_abuse_dependence_usual_amount)
Did this happen in the last 12 months? (substances_lifetime_abuse_dependence_usual_amount_past_year)
During the last 12 months, which medicines or drugs did this happen with? (substances_lifetime_abuse_dependence_usual_amount_past_year_drug_name)
Did this happen before 12 months ago, that is, before last?(Month one year ago)? (substances_lifetime_abuse_dependence_usual_amount_prior_last_year)
Which medicines or drugs did this happen with before 12 months ago? (substances_lifetime_abuse_dependence_usual_amount_prior_last_year_drug_names)
In your entire life, Did you EVER find that you had to use much more of a medicine or to get the effect you wanted? (substances_lifetime_abuse_dependence_more_same_effect)
Did this happen in the last 12 months? (substances_lifetime_abuse_dependence_more_same_effect_past_year)

You just mentioned that you had SOME bad aftereffects when stopping or cutting down on your use of medicines or drugs in the last 12 months. Did at least 2 of these experiences happen around the same time DURING the last 12 months? (substances_lifetime_abuse_dependence_after_effects_stop_use_past_year)
In your entire life, Did you EVER take more of the same or a similar medicine or drug to get over or avoid any of these bad aftereffects? (substances_lifetime_abuse_dependence_more_same_drug)
Did this happen in the last 12 months? (substances_lifetime_abuse_dependence_more_same_drug_past_year)

protocol.preferredDefinition: Respondents answer questions from the National Epidemiologic Survey on Alcohol and Related Conditions-III (NESARC-III) related to their lifetime use of illicit and prescribed substances.

form.longName: PhenX PX161602 - Personal History Of Allergies Infectious Dis
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol is a self- or proxy-administered personal health record from the American Health Information Management Association (AHIMA). The respondent is asked to provide details on the following categories: Medical History, Infectious Diseases, Immunizations, Allergies/Drug Sensitivities, Health Log, Doctor Visits, Hospitalizations, Surgeries, Lab or Imaging, Medical Devices, and Physical/Occupational Therapy.

protocol.longName: Personal History of Allergies, Infectious Diseases, and Immunizations - Adult
protocol.preferredDefinition: This protocol is a self- or proxy-administered personal health record from the American Health Information Management Association (AHIMA). The respondent is asked to provide details on the following categories: Medical History, Infectious Diseases, Immunizations, Allergies/Drug Sensitivities, Health Log, Doctor Visits, Hospitalizations, Surgeries, Lab or Imaging, Medical Devices, and Physical/Occupational Therapy.

form.longName: PhenX PX230101 - Eating Disorders Examination Child Interview
form.preferredDefinition: The Eating Disorder Examination (EDE) interview for children is a clinical interview assessment of eating disorder psychopathology (including anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, and binge-eating disorder) based on the Fifth Edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5). The interview includes items related to the respondent behaviors that are potentially indicative of an eating disorder over the past 4 weeks (28 days).

headerInstruction.text: 1. INTRODUCTION: The idea is to get a general picture of the subjects eating habits. It is very difficult for children to get a clear grasp of the time span being discussed. Hopefully, we will have an agenda for the last three months that has been completed by the child's parent. At this point, ask the child if they think that the agenda is accurate, and if there were any other significant events that occurred over the last three months that they would like to add to the agenda. The child then keeps this agenda on which all this information is written throughout the interview and should be encouraged to refer to it.Having used this agenda to orient the child to the specific time period being assessed, use the following questions as guidelines to ascertain the child's general eating habits.*To start with I'd like to get an idea of how your eating has been over the last four weeks.

question.questionText: Has your eating been very different from one day to the next? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_introduction)
Has your eating on weekends been different to days during the week? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_introduction_weekend)
Have there been any days when you haven't eaten anything at all? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_introduction_fasting)
Recent sick days or vacation days during which you're eating might have been different? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_introduction_sickdays)
What about during the past two months? (NB at this point you will almost certainly have to use the agenda to aid recall.) (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_introduction_twomonths)

THE KEY PROBLEM: Occasionally children will say that they "don't know" why it is they are avoiding certain foods etc. and therefore can't answer the key part of the item - is it to influence your weight or shape? Thus, on these items, they cannot be marked for these behaviors. However, when it becomes clearer later on that these are their main concerns and therefore prime motivation for engaging in a particular behavior - Fairburn suggests that you can go back and re-rate, although he may not have had such core concepts in mind (problem_230101)

SCORING DECISIONS: a) It has been decided to rate child's answers as what they would do if they were allowed to by their parents. For example, for social eating children are made to do this but would almost certainly avoid it if they could, and therefore this should be rated as avoiding.b) A lot of children put their answer under a cover of "I used to ... but now I feel differently". In the pilot study, this was often not convincing (although not exactly lying) but had to be rated as child answered, and hence some scores may be consistently underrating the child's psychopathology. (scoring_intro_230101)

2. PATTERN OF EATING: Essence of question: To get a clear picture of child's eating habits over the last 7 days. Questions to ask: *I would like to ask about your pattern of eating: Over the past 7 days (not including today), which of these meals or snacks have you eaten regularly? (Check understanding of regularly). Guidelines * Ask about weekdays and weekends separately * Meals or snacks should be rated even if they lead on to a "binge"* "Brunch" should generally be classified as lunch. Rating: Rate each meal and snack separately, usually accepting the subject's classification.Rate up (i.e., give a higher rating) if it is difficult to choose between two ratings. Rate 8 if means or snacks are difficult to classify. Rate each meal according to the rating table below. If a usual week, ask about a typical week in the past month. Scoring: Fill in the brackets after each meal with the most appropriate score from the table below. (pattern_230101)
Over the past 7 days (not including today), which of these meals or snacks have you eaten regularly during the week? (check all that apply) (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_patternofeating_meals_week)

validValue.meaningText: Nocturnal snack (i.e., after having been asleep)
validValue.description: Nocturnal snack (i.e., after having been asleep)

question.questionText: 3. RESTRAINT OVER EATING (Restraint subscale) Essence of question: To ascertain whether the child has consciously been attempting to restrict what he/she eats, regardless of whether their attempts have been successful. (restraint_230101)
Over the past four weeks, have you deliberately been trying to cut down on what you eat, even if you haven't managed to do this? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_restraintovereating_history)
How often? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_restraintovereating_frequency)
What is the purpose of cutting down? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_restraintovereating_purpose)
Have you done this to try to change your shape or weight? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_restraintovereating_shapeweight)

Guidelines * The restraint should have been intended to influence shape, weight or body composition, although this may not be the sole of main reason. * It should have consisted of planned attempts at restriction, rather than spur of the moment attempts such as the decision to resist a second helping. Rating: Rate the number of days on which the subject has consciously attempted to restrict his/her food intake, whether or not he/she has succeeded. (rest_guide_230101)

Which rating best describes the number of days on which the subject has consciously attempted to restrict his/her food instake, whether or not he/she has succeeded? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_restraintovereating_rating)

validValue.meaningText: 2 - Attempted to exercise restraint on less than half the days
validValue.description: 2 - Attempted to exercise restraint on less than half the days

validValue.meaningText: 4 - Attempted to exercise restraint on more than half the days
validValue.description: 4 - Attempted to exercise restraint on more than half the days

validValue.meaningText: 6 - Attempted to exercise restraint every day
validValue.description: 6 - Attempted to exercise restraint every day

question.questionText: 4. AVOIDANCE OF EATING (Restraint subscale) Essence of question: To ascertain whether the child has gone for periods of 8 hours or more without eating, and if not, would they, were they allowed. In either instance, determine how often this occurred over the past four weeks. (avoidance_230101)
Over the past four weeks, have you ever not eaten anything for most of the day? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_avoidanceofeating_history)
If so, about what time would you decide to not eat? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_avoidanceofeating_time)
About what time would you start eating again? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_avoidanceofeating_starttime)
How often has this happened? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_avoidanceofeating_frequency)
Why have you done this? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_avoidanceofeating_purpose)
Have you done this to try and change your shape and weight? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_avoidanceofeating_shapeweight)

Guidelines: * It may be helpful to illustrate the length of time (e.g., 9am to 5pm). * The abstinence must have been at least partly self-imposed, rather than being due to force of circumstance. * It should have been intended to influence shape, weight or body composition, although this may not have been the sole or main reason. * Check that avoidance has not been to annoy a parent. (avoid_guide_230101)

Which rating best describes the number of days on which there has been at least eight hours abstinence from eating food (soup and milk-shakes count as food, whereas drinks in general do not) during waking hours? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_avoidanceofeating_rating)

validValue.meaningText: 2 - Avoidance on less than half the days
validValue.description: 2 - Avoidance on less than half the days

validValue.meaningText: 4 - Avoidance on more than half the days
validValue.description: 4 - Avoidance on more than half the days

question.questionText: 5. EMPTY STOMACH (Restraint subscale) Essence of question: To ascertain whether the child has a definite desire to have an empty stomach and if so, how often. It is important to differentiate between the desire to have an empty stomach and the desire for the stomach to feel empty or be flat. (stomach_230101)
Over the past four weeks, have you wanted your tummy to be empty - I mean not to have anything in it at all? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_emptystomach_history)
Why have you wanted to have an empty stomach? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_emptystomach_purpose)
Is it because you like to feel hungry? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_emptystomach_hungry)
How often have you wanted this? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_emptystomach_frequency)
Guidelines * This item must be differentiated from a desire for the stomach to FEEL empty or to be flat. (stomach_guide_230101)

Which rating best describes the number of days on which the subject has a definite desire to have a completely empty stomach for reasons to do with dieting, shape or weight? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_emptystomach_rating)

validValue.meaningText: 0 - No definite desire to have an empty stomach
validValue.description: 0 - No definite desire to have an empty stomach

validValue.meaningText: 2 - Definite desire to have an empty stomach on less than half the days
validValue.description: 2 - Definite desire to have an empty stomach on less than half the days

validValue.meaningText: 4 - Definite desire to have an empty stomach on more than half the days
validValue.description: 4 - Definite desire to have an empty stomach on more than half the days

validValue.meaningText: 6 - Definite desire to have an empty stomach every day
validValue.description: 6 - Definite desire to have an empty stomach every day

question.questionText: 6. FOOD AVOIDANCE (Restraint subscale) Essence of question: To ascertain whether, and how often, the child has been attempting to avoid liked foods, whether successful in those attempts or not. (food_avoidance_230101)
What foods do you really like/did you like before? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_foodavoidance_favorite)
Over the past four weeks have you tried to not eat any foods that you especially like, even if you haven't managed this? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_foodavoidance_history)
How often? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_foodavoidance_frequency)
Why have you stopped eating those foods? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_foodavoidance_reason)
Have you done this to try to change your shape or weight? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_foodavoidance_shapeweight)

Guidelines: * The goal should have been to avoid the foods altogether and not merely to restrict their consumption. * Drinks do not count as food. * The avoidance should have been intended to influence shape, weight or body composition, although this may not have been the sole or main reason. * It should be a strong desire, not a passing thought. (food_avoid_guide_230101)

Which rating best describes the number of days on which the subject has actively attempted to avoid eating specific foods (which he/she likes) whether or not he/she has succeeded? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_foodavoidance_rating)

validValue.meaningText: 2 - Attempted to avoid food on less than half the days
validValue.description: 2 - Attempted to avoid food on less than half the days

validValue.meaningText: 4 - Attempted to avoid food on more than half the days
validValue.description: 4 - Attempted to avoid food on more than half the days

validValue.meaningText: 6 - Attempted to avoid food every day
validValue.description: 6 - Attempted to avoid food every day

question.questionText: 7. DIETARY RULES. (Restraint Subscale) Essence of question: To ascertain whether the child has any dietary rules as opposed to general eating principles, and if so, how often the child attempts to obey these rules. (diet_rules_230101)

Over the past four weeks have you tried to stick to certain definite rules about your eating; for example, only allowing yourself a certain number of calories, or a certain amount of food, or rules about what you should eat or when you should eat? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dietaryrules_history)
Have there been times when you know you have broken one of your own rules about eating? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dietaryrules_brokenrules)
Would you keep to them if you were not made to break them by your parents? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dietaryrules_parentalcontrol)
How have you felt about breaking them? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dietaryrules_feelings)
How would you have felt if you had broken one of your eating rules? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dietaryrules_brokenfeeling)
What are your rules? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dietaryrules_details)
Why have you tried to stick to them? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dietaryrules_reason)
Did you make them to try to change your shape or weight? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dietaryrules_shapeweight)
Do you try to stick to them every day? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dietaryrules_daily)
If not, how often do you try to stick to them? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dietaryrules_notdaily)

Are they about certain foods or are they more general? Please describe (You will need to give some examples at this point. Examples of definite rules would be "I must not eat eggs" or "I must not eat cake", whereas a general principle would be "I should try to eat healthy food". (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dietaryrules_certainfoods)

Guidelines: * Dietary rules should be rated as present if the subject has been attempting to follow "definite" (i.e., specific) dietary rules regarding his/her food intake. * The rules should have been self-imposed, although originally they may have been prescribed. * They should have been concerned with what the subject should have eaten or when eating should have taken place. They might consist of a calorie limit (e.g., below 1,200 calories a day), not eating before a certain time of day, not eating certain kinds of food, or not eating at all. * There should have been specific rules and not general guidelines, and there may have been distress should they have been broken. * If the subject is aware that she has occasionally broken a personal dietary rule, this suggests that one or more specific rules has been present. In such cases the interviewer should ask in detain about the transgression in an attempt to identify the underlying rule. * The rules should have been intended to influence shape, weight or body composition, although this may not have been the sole or main reason. * Ensure that the dietary rules are not purely, for example, obsessive compulsive or control related. * It should be noted that "dietary rules" are regarded as having been present if there have been clear attempts to obey specific dietary rules. (diet_rules_guide_230101)

Which rating best describes the number of days on which the subject has actively attempted to adhere to his/her dietary rule(s) from the past four weeks? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dietaryrules_rating)

question.questionText: 8. PREOCCUPATION WITH FOOD, EATING OR CALORIES (Eating Concern subscale) Essence of question: To ascertain whether thinking about food, etc. has at any time impaired concentration, and if so, how often. (preoccupation_230101)

Over the past four weeks have you spent much time between meals thinking about food, eating or calories (not because you were hungry)? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_preoccupationfoodeatingcalories_history)
How often? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_preoccupationfoodeatingcalories_frequency)
Has thinking about food, eating or calories made it hard for you to concentrate on or pay attention to what you are doing? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_preoccupationfoodeatingcalories_distraction)

How about concentrating on things that you like doing, like watching television, reading, playing computer games (etc.)? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_preoccupationfoodeatingcalories_distraction_hobbies)
Could you stop thinking about food if you tried? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_preoccupationfoodeatingcalories_discipline)

Guidelines: * Concentration is regarded as impaired if there have been intrusive thoughts about food, eating or calories which have interfered with activities. * Ask if the child could stop thinking about food if they tried, in order to ascertain whether the thoughts are intrusive or not. (preoccup_guide_230101)

Which rating best describes the number of days on which concentration has been impaired due to preoccupation with food, eating or calories, whether or not bulimic episodes have occurred? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_preoccupationfoodeatingcalories_rating)

validValue.meaningText: 2 - Concentration impairment on less than half the days
validValue.description: 2 - Concentration impairment on less than half the days

validValue.meaningText: 4 - Concentration impairment on more than half the days
validValue.description: 4 - Concentration impairment on more than half the days

question.questionText: 9. FEAR OF LOSING CONTROL OVER EATING (Eating concern subscale) Essence of question: To ascertain how often a fear of losing control over eating has occurred, regardless of whether the child felt in control of his/her eating behaviors (lose_control_230101)
Over the past four weeks have you been frightened of losing control over eating? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_fearlosingcontrol_history)

Have you been afraid that you won't be able to stop eating? (That is, once you've started eating, have you been scared that you won't be able to stop, or have you avoided starting to eat because of fears that you won't be able to stop eating when you wanted to?) (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_fearlosingcontrol_discipline)
How often have you felt like this? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_fearlosingcontrol_frequency)

Guidelines: * You are looking to identify instances of fear of losing control as opposed to instances of loss of control. * "Loss of control" involves a sense that one will not be able to resist or stop eating. (lose_control_guide_230101)

Which rating best describes the number of days on which definite fear has been present, irrespective of whether the subject feels he/she has been in control? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_fearlosingcontrol_rating)

validValue.meaningText: 2 - Fear of losing control present on less than half the days
validValue.description: 2 - Fear of losing control present on less than half the days

validValue.meaningText: 4 - Fear of losing control present on more than half the days
validValue.description: 4 - Fear of losing control present on more than half the days

validValue.meaningText: 6 - Fear of losing control present every day
validValue.description: 6 - Fear of losing control present every day

question.questionText: 10. BULIMIC EPISODES AND OTHER EPISODES OF OVEREATING (Diagnostic item) Essence of question: To determine how many episodes of each of four different types of overeating have occurred (if any) in the specified period. (bulimic_230101)

Guidelines for interviewers: Four forms of overeating are distinguished. The distinction is based upon the presence or absence of two characteristics: i) Loss of control (required for both types of "bulimic episode") ii) The consumption of what would generally be regarded as large amounts of food (required for both types of "objective" episodes). To facilitate the decision of what kind of overeating episode has occurred, use this table: (bulimic_guide_230101)
IMAGE: table (image_table1)

The interviewer should ask about each form of overeating. It is important to note that the forms of overeating are not mutually exclusive: it is possible for subjects to have had several different forms of overeating episodes over the preceding month.Definition of key terms: Loss of control: The interviewer should ask the subject whether he or she experienced a loss of control over eating at the time that the episode of overeating occurred. * If this is clearly described, loss of control should be rated as present. * Loss of control may be rated positively even if the episode has been planned. * If the subject uses terms such as "driven to eat" etc., loss of control should be rated as present. For chronic cases only: * If the subject reports no sense of loss of control, yet describes having not been able to stop eating once eating had started, or having not been able to prevent the episode from occurring, loss of control should be rated as present. * If the subjects report that they are no longer trying to control their eating because overeating is inevitable, loss of control should be rated as present. If the interviewer is in doubt, loss of control should be rated as absent. * Large amount of food. The decision whether or not the amount eaten was "large" should be made by the interviewer and should not require the agreement of the subject. * "Large" may be used to refer to the amount of any particular types or the overall quantity of food consumed. * The interviewer should take into account what would be the usual amount eaten under the circumstances. This required some knowledge of the eating habits of the subject's general (but not necessarily immediate) social group. * What else was eaten and whether or not the subject subsequently spits or vomits the food. If the interviewer is in doubt, the amount should not be classified as large. The number of episodes of overeating. When calculating the number of episodes of overeating, th..TRUNCATED (definitions_230101)

I'd like to ask you about any times you have really eaten too much during the past four weeks. Can you tell me about any times when you have felt that you have eaten too much in one go? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_bulimicepisodes_history)
(To assess amount eaten): What have you usually eaten at times like this? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_bulimicepisodes_food)
(To assess amount eaten): What was/were the rest of your family/friends eating when it happened? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_bulimicepisodes_food_others)
(To assess loss of control): Did you feel out of control, or that you just couldn't stop when it happened? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_bulimicepisodes_control)
(Chronic case only):Could you have made yourself stop eating once you had started? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_bulimicepisodes_discipline)
(Chronic case only): Could you have somehow stopped yourself from starting to overeat in the first place? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_bulimicepisodes_initialdiscipline)

Ask about the frequency of episodes, both over the last four weeks, and over the preceding two months. Scoring: For objective bulimic episodes, subjective bulimic episodes and episodes of objective overeating, make the following ratings: In general, it is best to calculate the number of days first, and then number of episodes. Rate 9 if you do not ask about the preceding two months. Episodes of subjective overeating are not rated. (bulimic_score_230101)
How often have you felt like this in the past four weeks? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_bulimicepisodes_frequency_month)

AGE OF ONSET SECTION [Code -99 if a question was not asked or if it was deemed not applicable. Do not code a range like 4-5 or 40-50 (ex: for age of LOC onset or for number of diets ever). If the participant is not able to give an exact number, take the average (4.5 or 45). You can then confirm with the participant that the average seems like the best number. Rate 777 if the number is so great that it cannot be calculated.] (age_of_onset_230101)

11. DIETARY RESTRICTION OUTSIDE BULIMIC EPISODES (Diagnostic item) Only ask this question if at least 12 objective and/or subjective bulimic episodes have occurred over the last three months. Essence of question: To ascertain to what degree the subject cuts down on the amount he/she eats (outside of bulimic episodes) in order to change his/her shape or weight. Essentially, this is an overview of the periods that the subject has been in control over the last three months. (diet_restrict_230101)
Apart from these times when you have been out of control with your eating, how much have you been cutting down on the amount you eat? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dietaryrestrictions_amount)
What have you usually been eating in a day? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dietaryrestrictions_details)
Have you done this to try to change your shape or weight? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dietaryrestrictions_shapeweight)

Guidelines: * Ask about actual food intake outside the objective and subjective bulimic episodes. * Any dietary restriction should have been intended to influence shape, weight or body composition, although this may not have been the sole or main reason. Rating : * Rate the average degree of dietary restriction. *Rate each of the past three months separately. * Rate 9 if not asked. (diet_restrict_guide_230101)

question.questionText: 12. SOCIAL EATING (Eating concern subscale) Essence of question: To ascertain whether the child has belt concerned about other people seeing them eat, and also whether they have avoided eating in front of others. (social_eating_230101)
Over the past four weeks have you been worried about other people seeing you eat? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_socialeating_history)
Have you tried putting off (or getting out of) eating with other people? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_socialeating_avoidance)
Would you avoid eating in front of others if you were allowed to by your parents? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_socialeating_avoidance_parents)
Why were you concerned about others seeing you eat? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_socialeating_avoidance_reason)

Guidelines: * DO NOT CONSIDER objective or subjective bulimic episodes. In other words this item is to do with concern and avoidance of eating normal or less than normal amounts of food in front of others. *Make sure you find out the reasons or concern/avoidance. The reasons should be to do with, for example, the amount they are eating or for shape and weight reasons, NOT because they are afraid they may dribble their food! Rating: Rate the degree of concern about eating normal or less than normal amounts of food in front of others (e.g., family) and whether this has led to avoidance. This rating should represent the average for the month. If the possibility of eating with others has not arisen, rate 9. A child may feel a definite concern, but not be able to avoid eating in public, due to parental pressure. If this is the case, rate 8. (social_eat_guide_230101)

Which rating best describes the concern about eating normal or less than normal amounts of food in front of others (e.g., family) and whether this has led to avoidance? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_socialeating_rating)

validValue.meaningText: 0 - No concern about being seen eating by others and no avoidance of such occasions.
validValue.description: 0 - No concern about being seen eating by others and no avoidance of such occasions.

validValue.meaningText: 2 - Has felt slight concern about being seen, but no avoidance.
validValue.description: 2 - Has felt slight concern about being seen, but no avoidance.

question.questionText: 13. EATING IN SECRET (Eating concern subscale) Essence of question: To ascertain whether and how often the child has eaten in secret. (eat_secretly_230101)
Over the past four weeks, have you eaten in secret? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_eatinginsecret_history)
How often? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_eatinginsecret_frequency)
Rating: Rate the number of days on which there has been at least one episode of secret eating. If the possibility of eating with others has not arisen, rate 9. (eat_secretly_guide_230101)
Which rating best describes the number of days on which there has been at least one episode of secret eating? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_eatinginsecret_rating)

validValue.meaningText: 2 - Has eaten in secret on less than half the days.
validValue.description: 2 - Has eaten in secret on less than half the days.

validValue.meaningText: 4 - Has eaten in secret on more than half the days.
validValue.description: 4 - Has eaten in secret on more than half the days.

validValue.meaningText: 6 - Has eaten in secret every day.
validValue.description: 6 - Has eaten in secret every day.

validValue.meaningText: 9 - The possibility of eating with others has not occurred.
validValue.description: 9 - The possibility of eating with others has not occurred.

question.questionText: 14. GUILT ABOUT EATING (Eating concern subscale) Essence of question: To ascertain whether, and how often the child, has felt as if he/she was doing something wrong by eating. (guilt_230101)
Over the past four weeks, have you felt that you have done something wrong during or after eating? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_guiltabouteating_history)
Have you felt guilty about eating? By that I mean, have you felt bad about eating and felt that you shouldn't have done it? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_guiltabouteating_guilt)
Why? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_guiltabouteating_reason)
How often when you have eaten, have you felt it was wrong or that you shouldn't have? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_guiltabouteating_frequency)

Guidelines: * DO NOT CONSIDER Objective or subjective bulimic episodes. * The feelings of guilt should relate to the effects of eating on shape, weight or body composition. * Distinguish guilt from regret: guilt refers to a feeling that one has done wrong; regret is a desire not to have done something. The child may have guilt coupled with regret, but ensure that following eating, the child felt as if he/she had been bad or done wrong. Rating: Rate the proportion of times on which feelings of guilt has followed eating. NB This rating is based on number of occasions, NOT days. (guilt_guide_230101)
Which rating best describes the proportion of times on which feelings of guilt has followed eating? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_guiltabouteating_rating)

validValue.meaningText: 2 - Has felt guilty after eating on less than half the occasions
validValue.description: 2 - Has felt guilty after eating on less than half the occasions

validValue.meaningText: 4 - Has felt guilty after eating on more than half the occasions
validValue.description: 4 - Has felt guilty after eating on more than half the occasions

validValue.meaningText: 6 - Has felt guilty after eating on every occasion
validValue.description: 6 - Has felt guilty after eating on every occasion

question.questionText: 15. SELF-INDUCED VOMITING (Diagnostic item) Essence of question: To ascertain whether, and how often, the child is using self-induced vomiting as a means of controlling his/her shape or weight. (self_induced_vomit_230101)
(For ethical reasons). When was the last time you were physically sick/vomited? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_selfinducedvomiting_history)
What happened then? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_selfinducedvomiting_details)

(If necessary ...) Have there been times when you have eaten more than you have been happy with and felt that you have had to do something about it? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_selfinducedvomiting_history_selfrealization)
Some people feel so desperate sometimes that they even try to make themselves sick. Have you ever done this? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_selfinducedvomiting_inducesickness)
If so, was this during the last four weeks? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_selfinducedvomiting_inducesickness_history)
Did you do this to try to keep you weight down / to stop you from getting fat / putting on weight? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_selfinducedvomiting_shapeweight)

Ask about the frequency of episodes, both over the last four weeks, and over the preceding two months. Guidelines: Ensure that the main reason is in order to control shape or weight. (self_induced_vomit_guide_230101)
What is the number of days in the past four weeks on which there has been self-induced vomiting? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_selfinducedvomiting_days_month)

What is the number of days between the past 8 to 12 weeks on which there has been self-induced vomiting? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_selfinducedvomiting_days_threemonths)

16. LAXATIVE MISUSE (Diagnostic item) Essence of question: To ascertain whether, and how often, the child is misusing laxatives as a means of controlling his/her shape or weight. (laxative_230101)
Are there medicines around that make you go to the toilet? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_laxativemisuse_present)
Have you ever taken any of these (over the last four weeks)? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_laxativemisuse_history)
If yes, why (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_laxativemisuse_reason)
Was this to make sure that you didn't put any weight on or get too fat? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_laxativemisuse_shapeweight)
What did you take? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_laxativemisuse_type)
How much did you take? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_laxativemisuse_amount)

Guidelines: * If the child has taken pills or medicine, ensure that you are talking about laxatives, not diuretics or any other form of medication * To be classed as misuse, laxatives must have been taken at a dose of at least twice the recommended amount. (laxative_guide_230101)

What is the number of days in the past 4 weeks on which laxatives have been taken as a means of controlling shape, weight or body composition? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_laxativemisuse_days_month)

18. INTENSE EXERCISE TO CONTROL SHAPE OR WEIGHT (UNREVISED) (Diagnostic item) Essence of question: To ascertain how much (if any) exercise the child does in order to control his/her shape or weight. [Start this item with a review of the difference between shape, or how your body looks in the mirror, image on left, versus weight, or the number on the scale, image on right side] (intense_exercise_230101)
IMAGE: 230101_img_1 (image_230101_img_1)
What sort of exercise does you usually do? How often? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_intenseexercise_type)
Which sports do you participate in? How often? (psychopathologyeating2_59a)
Over the past four weeks, have you exercised / done sport / worked out in order to keep your weight down? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_intenseexercise_history)
Have you exercised to change your shape? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_intenseexercise_shape)
Which parts of you were you trying to change? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_intenseexercise_bodyparts)
Have you exercised to try to burn off calories / use up the food that you have eaten? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_intenseexercise_burncalories_alreadyeaten)

Ask about the frequency of episodes, both over the last four weeks, and over the preceding two months. Guidelines: * Find out whether the exercise is for fun, or predominantly to do with shape or weight. The exercise must be intense and predominantly intended to burn off calories or change shape, weight or body composition. * The decision whether the exercise was "intense" should be made by the interviewer. * If in doubt, the exercising should not be classified as intense * Discount any exercise that was done purely for enjoyment. * Watch out for children who abuse the group activity, for example, running around fare more than is necessary, and far more than others in a "fun" setting such as a football team. (intense_exer_guide_230101)

Rating: Rate the number of days that the subject has engaged in intense exercise that was predominantly intended to use calories or change shape, weight or body composition. Rate the average amount of time, in minutes, per day spent exercising in this way. Only consider days on which the subject exercised. If you do not ask about the preceding two months, rate 99. (int_exer_rate_230101)

What is the number of days in the past four weeks that the subject engaged in intense exercise that was predominantly intended to use calories or change shape, weight or body composition? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_intenseexercise_days_month_encoded)

19. OTHER EXTREME METHODS FOR CONTROLLING SHAPE OR WEIGHT (Diagnostic item) Essence of question: To ascertain whether the child has engaged in any other forms of extreme weight/shape control behavior. (oth_extreme_exer_230101)
Over the past four weeks, have you done anything else to try to change your shape or weight? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_otherextrememethods_history)
If Yes, please specify the nature of these acts: (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_otherextrememethods_details)

Ask about the frequency of episodes, both over the last four weeks, and over the preceding two months. Guidelines: * Examples of other forms of extreme weight/shape control behavior include misusing appetite suppressants, spitting out food, and under-using insulin in those subjects weight insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. * Different acts should be combined to derive a total for the past four weeks. * The behavior does not have to have been effective in controlling weight, shape or body composition, merely present. (oth_ext_exer_guide_230101)

What is the number of days in the past 4 weeks that the child has engaged in extreme forms of behavior designed to influence weight, shape or body composition, irrespective of whether they are likely to have been effective? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_otherextrememethods_days_month_encoded)

What is the number of occasions in the past 4 weeks that the child has engaged in extreme forms of behavior designed to influence weight, shape or body composition, irrespective of whether they are likely to have been effective? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_otherextrememethods_occasions_month_encoded)

20. ABSTINENCE FROM EXTREME WEIGHT CONTROL BEHAVIOR (Diagnostic item) ONLY ASK THIS QUESTION IF AT LEAST ONE OF THE KEY FORMS OF WEIGHT CONTROL BEHAVIOR HAS BEEN RATED POSITIVELY AT THE SPECIFIED SEVERITY LEVEL OVER THE PAST THREE MONTHS. Essence of question: To ascertain whether the child has abstained from any particular form of weight controlling behavior over the last three months. (q20_230101)
The five forms of behavior is as follows: * Fasting * Self-induced vomiting * Laxative misuse * Diuretic misuse * Excessive exercise (five_behav_230101)
Over the past three months has there been a period of two or more weeks when you have not ... FASTED? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_abstinence_history)
Over the past three months has there been a period of two or more weeks when you have not ... SELF INDUCED VOMITED? (psychopathologyeating_vomit)
Over the past three months has there been a period of two or more weeks when you have not ... MISUSED LAXATIVES? (psycho_eat_lax_misuse)
Over the past three months has there been a period of two or more weeks when you have not ... MISUSED DIURETICS? (psycho_eat_diuretic_misuse)
Over the past three months has there been a period of two or more weeks when you have not ... EXERCISED EXCESSIVELY? (psycho_eat_exer_exces)

Guidelines: * Ascertain the number of consecutive weeks over the past three months "free" (i.e., not above threshold levels) from all five forms of extreme weight control behavior. * Ascertain whether abstinence was due to force of circumstance (e.g., being in hospital). (abst_ext_beha_230101)

What is the number of consecutive weeks over the past three months free from all five forms of extreme weight control behavior? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_abstinence_null_consecutiveweeks_encoded)
What is the number of consecutive weeks over the past three months free from all five forms of extreme weight control behavior? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_abstinence_null_consecutiveweeks)
21. DISSATISFACTION WITH WEIGHT (Weight concern subscale) Essence of question: To ascertain whether the child has felt dissatisfied and distressed about his/her WEIGHT. (dissatified_wgt_230101)
Over the past four weeks, how have you felt about your weight? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dissatisfactionwithweight_history)
Have you felt dissatisfied with your weight? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dissatisfactionwithweight_disatisfaction)
Has this made you really miserable or unhappy? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dissatisfactionwithweight_miserable)

Guidelines: * Dissatisfaction should only be taken into account if it is due to weight being too high. * When asking about the level of distress felt due to dissatisfaction with weight, do not prompt the child with the terms "slight", "moderate" or "marked". * The child's attitude towards his/her weight should be assessed by the interviewer. * Ensure that you are talking about WEIGHT dissatisfaction and not shape dissatisfaction. * Try to find out how much dissatisfaction surrounds the child's weight, e.g., two days per month, 28 days per month, and rate on severity. Rating: Rate the child's attitude to his/her weight. This should represent the average for the entire month. Only rate 4, 5 or 6 if there has been distress. Rate 9 if the subject is unaware of his/her weight. (dissatif_wgt_230101)
Which rating best describes the child's attitude to his/her weight? This should represent the average for the entire month. (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dissatisfactionwithweight_rating)

validValue.meaningText: 6 - Marked dissatisfaction (extreme concern and distress; weight totally unacceptable)
validValue.description: 6 - Marked dissatisfaction (extreme concern and distress; weight totally unacceptable)

Have you had a very strong wish to lose weight? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_desireloseweight_wish)
Guidelines : Remember that this item is concerned with WEIGHT and not shape. (desire_lose_wgt_guide_230101)
Which rating best describes the number of days on which there has been a strong desire to lose weight? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_desireloseweight_rating)

Has this made you really miserable or unhappy? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_dissatisfactionwithshape_miserable)

question.questionText: 26. PREOCCUPATION WITH SHAPE OR WEIGHT (Shape and weight concern subscale) Essence of question: To ascertain whether thinking about his/her shape or weight has impaired the child's ability to concentrate on things that he/she enjoys doing (preoccup_shape_230101)

Over the last four weeks, have you spend much time thinking about your shape or weight? (Check that the child has grasped these concepts). (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_preoccupationshapeweight_history)
Has thinking about your shape or weight made it hard for you to pay attention to what you are doing? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_preoccupationshapeweight_distraction)

What about when you are doing things that you enjoy, for instance, watching television, reading, playing computer games (etc.)? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_preoccupationshapeweight_distraction_hobbies)
How often does this happen? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_preoccupationshapeweight_frequency)

Rating: The interviewer must be convinced that intrusive thoughts about shape and weight are leading to an inability to concentrate on things that the child enjoys doing, in order to rate concentration impairment is present. (preocc_shape_guide_230101)
Which rating best describes the number of days on which this has happened? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_preoccupationshapeweight_rating)

question.questionText: 27./28. IMPORTANCE OF SHAPE AND IMPORTANCE OF WEIGHT (2 Diagnostic items and weight concern subscale/shape concern subscale) Essence of question: To ascertain how important the child's shape and weight are in influencing how they evaluate themselves as a person. (import_shape_wgt_230101)

Introduction: *People have different ways that they feel about (judge, think, evaluate) themselves. I want to ask you about how you evaluate yourself." *Let me give you an example. When your teacher gives you a grade, he or she uses several things to evaluate you as a student, such as: attendance, how you do on tests, class participation, homework, being on time to school, etc." *I want to know what you use to evaluate yourself as a person. I'd like to make a list with you of four or five things that you use to evaluate yourself. I will write each one of these things on a card." Most children completely understand the question at this point, and offer up several examples of what they use to evaluate themselves. However, if they do not, use the ensuing probe. *For some people, they use doing well at school to evaluate themselves; for others, being kind to animals, how they get along with their friends or family, playing sports, involvement in clubs or other activities, etc. (Give the child loads of examples, or else they may just repeat your two or three - by giving lots, they have to think about it a little bit more.) For each you should clarify its status by saying: "So being nice to your brother is one of the things you use to evaluate yourself?" When you have a list of four or five things written on cards, if they haven't said their "shape" or "weight," introduce these to the list and write them on the cards also. (intro2_230101)
Do you use your shape to evaluate yourself? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_importanceshapeweight_shape_evaluation)
Do you use your weight to evaluate yourself? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_importanceshapeweight_weight_evaluation)

Which rating best describes the number of days in the past 4 weeks on which the subject evaluates him/herself based on his/her shape? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_importanceshapeweight_shape_month)

question.questionText: 29. FEAR OF WEIGHT GAIN (Diagnostic item) Essence of question: To ascertain whether the child has a definite fear of gaining weight. (fear_wgt_gain_230101)
Over the past four weeks, have you been scared that you might put on weight or get fat? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_fearweightgain_history)

Ask about the frequency of this fear, both over the last four weeks and over the preceding two months. Guidelines : * Exclude reactions to actual weight gain. * Anorectics are in control and can't perceive ever gaining weight. Whilst in control, it is unlikely that they will have fear of gaining weight. (fear_wgt_gain_guide_230101)

question.questionText: 30. DISCOMFORT SEEING BODY (Shape concern subscale) Essence of question: To ascertain whether, and to what degree, the subject feels any discomfort when seeing their body. (discomfort_body_230101)

Over the past four weeks, have you felt awkward or embarrassed seeing your own body, for example, in the mirror, reflected in a shop window, getting undressed, having a bath or shower? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_discomfortseeingbody_history)
Have you tried not looking at your body? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_discomfortseeingbody_avoidance)
If so, why? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_discomfortseeingbody_reason)
Which rating best describes the level of discomfort felt by the child, averaged out over the past four weeks? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_discomfortseeingbody_rating)

validValue.meaningText: 6 - Definite discomfort about seeing body and has attempted to avoid all such occasions (i.e., the child has attempted not to see his/her body at all, even when washing).
validValue.description: 6 - Definite discomfort about seeing body and has attempted to avoid all such occasions (i.e., the child has attempted not to see his/her body at all, even when washing).

question.questionText: 31. AVOIDANCE OF EXPOSURE (Shape concern subscale) Essence of question: To ascertain whether, and to what degree, the child feels any discomfort when other people see his/her body. (avoid_expos_230101)

Over the past four weeks, have you felt awkward or embarrassed when other people see your body, for instance, getting changed for swimming, in the swimming pool, if you are wearing shorts or a short skirt? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_avoidanceexposure_history)
What about when your parents / brother(s) / sister(s) / friends (male and female) can see your body? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_avoidanceexposure_familyfriends)
Have you tried not to let other people see your body? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_avoidanceexposure_others)
If so, why? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_avoidanceexposure_reason)

Guidelines: * The discomfort should be due to the child's sensitivity about the overall appearance of his/her shape or figure. * It should not stem from sensitivity about specific aspects of appearance (e.g., acne, big nose). * The discomfort should not stem from modesty. Rating: Rate the level of discomfort felt by the child, averaged out over the past four weeks. If the possibility of exposure has not arisen, rate 9. (avoid_expos_guide_230101)
Which rating best describes the level of discomfort felt by the child, averaged out over the past four weeks? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_avoidanceexposure_rating)

question.questionText: 32. FEELINGS OF FATNESS (Diagnostic item and shape concern subscale) Essence of question: To ascertain whether, and how often, the subject has felt fat over the last four weeks. (feel_fat_230101)
Over the past four weeks, have you felt fat? (psychopathologyeatingdisorders_feelingfatness_history)

Ask about the frequency of episodes, both over the last four weeks, and over the preceding two months. Guidelines : * Distinguish "feeling fat" from feeling bloated premenstrual, unless this is experienced as feeling fat * Accept the child's use of the expression "feeling fat". Rating: Rate the number of days on which the subject has felt fat. (feel_fat_guide_230101)

*Ask the following questions on the most pathological eating episode (from OBE to SBE to OO to NE/typical meal) within the past month (questions_230101)
IMAGE: 230101_img_2 (image_230101_img_2)
IMAGE: 230101_img_3 (image_230101_img_3)

Coding notes: One form per child. Circle each child's responses: If more than 1 response to a query, circle all responses and note all codes (numbers) on the summary form. If a response does not fit into a category, write in the new response and be sure to include the response on the summary form. If you are unclear on how to code a response, contact the team so that we can make a collaborative decision (coding_230101)

Subscale Items: Restraint: 3 Restraint over eating 4 Avoidance of eating 5 Empty stomach 6 Food avoidance 7 Dietary Rule . Eating Concern: 8 Preoccupation with food, eating or calorie.s 9 Fear of losing control over eating. 12 Social eating. 13 Eating in secret. 14 Guilt about eating. Shape Concern: 25 Dissatisfaction with shape 26 Preoccupation with shape or weight 27/28 Importance of shape and importance of weight 29 Fear of weight gain 30 Discomfort seeing body 31 Avoidance of exposure 32 Feelings of fatness 33 Flat stomach. Weight Concern: 21 Dissatisfaction with weight 22 Desire to lose weight 23 Desired Weight 24 Reaction to prescribed weighing 26 Preoccupation with shape or weight 27/28 Importance of shape and importance of weight (scoring_230101)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Eating Disorder Examination (EDE) interview for children is a clinical interview assessment of eating disorder psychopathology (including anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, and binge-eating disorder) based on the Fifth Edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5). The interview includes items related to the respondent behaviors that are potentially indicative of an eating disorder over the past 4 weeks (28 days).

form.longName: PhenX PX560201 - Comprehensive Hiv Risk Assessment
form.preferredDefinition: The National HIV Behavioral Surveillance System (NHBS) survey began in 2003 to determine risk behavior and HIV testing experiences. NHBS is conducted in cities with a high incidence of AIDS with three groups of people: men who have sex with men (MSM), injection drug users (IDU), and heterosexuals at high risk of exposure to HIV infection. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) provides funding to state and local health departments to collect the information. This is an interviewer-administered protocol that gathers sensitive information.

question.questionText: I'm going to ask you some questions about having sex. Please remember your answers will be kept private. GIVE RESPONDENT FLASHCARD H. 1 NOTE: The ashcards are located at the bottom of the questions. For these questions, "having sex" means oral, vaginal, or anal sex. Oral sex means mouth on the vagina or penis; vaginal sex means penis in the vagina; and anal sex means penis in the anus (butt). I need to ask you all the questions, even if some may not apply to your situation.Interviewer: Use your discretion in using slang terms for the following sexual behavior questions. (inst1_560201)

FOR MALE RESPONDENT ONLY Female Sex Partners (Male respondent) HET = Heterosexual; MSM = Men who have Sex with Men; IDU = Injection Drug Use;SX = Sexual Behavior; ID = Injection Drug; ND = Non-injection drug; HT = HIV Testing (inst2_560201)

ND-1. In the past 12 months, have you used any non-injection drugs, other than those prescribed for you? If ND-1 in (0, 7, 9), skip to Say Box before HT-1. If ND-1 in (0, 7, 9), skip to ND-3. (noninjectiondrugs_use)

SAY: I'm going to read you a list of drugs. For each drug I mention, please tell me how often you used it in the past 12 months. Do not include drugs you injected or drugs that were prescribed for you. GIVE RESPONDENT FLASHCARD K. (hgfgfgh)
ND-2.a How often did you use... Marijuana (noninjectiondrugs_frequency_marijuana)
ND-2.b.How often did you use...Crystal meth (tina, crank, or ice) (noninjectiondrugs_frequency_crystalmeth)
ND-2.c. How often did you use.... Crack cocaine (noninjectiondrugs_frequency_crack)
ND-2.d. How often did you use.....Powdered cocaine that is smoked or snorted (noninjectiondrugs_frequency_powdered_cocaine)
ND-2.e. How often did you use..... Downers such as Valium, Ativan, or Xanax (noninjectiondrugs_frequency_downers)
ND-2.f. How often did you use..... Painkillers such as OxyContin®, Vicodin®, or Percocet® (noninjectiondrugs_frequency_painkillers)
ND-2.g. How often did you use..... Hallucinogens such as LSD or mushrooms (noninjectiondrugs_frequency_hallucinogens)
ND-2.h. How often did you use...... X or Ecstasy (noninjectiondrugs_frequency_ecstasy)
ND-2.i. How often did you use.... Heroin that is smoked or snorted If NHBS-MSM, ask ND-2j through ND-2l. (noninjectiondrugs_frequency_heroin)
ND-2.k. How often did you use.... Poppers (amyl nitrate) (noninjectiondrugs_frequency_poppers)
ND-2.l. How often did you use.....GHB (noninjectiondrugs_frequency_ghb)
ND-2.l. How often did you use...... Special K (ketamine) (noninjectiondrugs_frequency_ketamine)
ND-2m1. In the past 12 months have you used any other non-injection drugs? (noninjectiondrugs_other)
ND-2m1. How often did you use.........Specify other drug If ND-2m1 in (0, 7, 9), skip to ND-3. (noninjectiondrugs_other_specify)
ND-2m2. In the past 12 months have you used any other non-injection drugs? If Respondent is not male, skip to Say Box before HT-1. (noninjectiondrugs_other_frequency)
ND-3. In the past 12 months, have you used Viagra®, Levitra®, or Cialis®? If ND-3 in (0, 7, 9), skip to Say Box before HT-1. (noninjectiondrugs_viagra)

ND-3.a. Did you use it to treat erectile dysfunction? If Respondent is male AND ID-3e or ND-2b are not 0 or 77, ask ND-3b. Otherwise, skip to Say Box before HT-1. (noninjectiondrugs_viagra_erectile_dysfunction)

ND-3b. You told me that you used crystal meth (tina, crank, or ice). In the past 12 months, did you use Viagra, Levitra or Cialis at the same time you used crystal meth? (noninjectiondrugs_viagra_and_crystalmeth)

module.longName: HIV Testing Experiences (HT) SAY: Now I'm going to ask you a few questions about getting tested for HIV. Remember, an HIV test checks whether someone has the virus that causes AIDS.
module.preferredDefinition: HIV Testing Experiences (HT) SAY: Now I'm going to ask you a few questions about getting tested for HIV. Remember, an HIV test checks whether someone has the virus that causes AIDS.

question.questionText: HT-1. Have you ever been tested for HIV? If HT-1 = 0, skip to HT-6. If HT-1 in (7, 9), Skip to Say Box before HT-9. (hiv_tested)
HT-2. When did you have your first HIV test? Month (hiv_first_test_month)
HT-2. When did you have your first HIV test? Year [77/7777 = Refused, 99/9999 = Don't know] (hiv_first_test_year)
CONF21. INTERVIEWER INSTRUCTIONS: HIV testing was not widely available before 1985. Please confirm the year. Is &[TST1TSTY] correct? (hiv_first_test_confirmprior1985)

validValue.meaningText: No Loop back to put in the correct year
validValue.description: No Loop back to put in the correct year

question.questionText: HT-3. In the past 2 years, that is, since [insert calculated month and year], how many times have you been tested for HIV? [77/7777 = Refused, 99/9999 = Don't know] ? If 0, 777, or 999, skip to HT-4 (hiv_past2year_tested_numbertimes)
HT-4. When did you have your most recent HIV test? Month (hiv_mostrecent_test_month)
HT-4. When did you have your most recent HIV test? Year [77/7777 = Refused, 99/9999 = Don't know] If Auto3 HT-4 is > 5 years ago, skip to HT-4c. (hiv_mostrecent_test_year)
CONF22. INTERVIEWER INSTRUCTIONS: HIV testing was not widely available before 1985. Please confirm the year. Is &[RCNTTSTY] correct? (hiv_mostrecent_test_confirmprior1985)

validValue.meaningText: No Loop back to put in the correct year
validValue.description: No Loop back to put in the correct year

question.questionText: HT-4a. When you got tested in ____ / ____ [insert date from HT-4], where did you get tested? Testing Site: (hiv_mostrecent_test_site)

HT-4a When you got tested in ____ / ____ [insert date from HT-4], where did you get tested? Testing Site: [Write down the site name and classify it from the list of choices below. Probe with additional questions if necessary. DO NOT read choices. Choose only ONE site type.] (hiv_mostrecent_test_site_classify)
HT-4b. When you got tested in ___ / ___ [insert date from HT-4], was it a rapid test where you could get your results within a couple of hours? (hiv_mostrecent_test_rapid)

HT-4c. What was the result of your most recent HIV test? [DO NOT Read choices, check only ONE.] If HT-4c = 1, go to Logic check before HT-6. If HT-4c = 2, skip to HT-7. If HT-4c in (7, 9), go to Logic Check before HT-6. (hiv_mostrecent_test_result)
HT-5. Before your test in ___ / ___ [insert date from HT-4], did you ever test positive for HIV? If HT-5 = 1, skip to HT-7a. (hiv_positiveresultbefore_mostrecent_test)

INTERVIEWER INSTRUCTIONS: Refer to HT-4. LAST HIV TEST WAS DONE (Check one): [PERSONS WHO HAVE NEVER TESTED HIV + AND HAVE NOT TESTED FOR HIV IN THE PAST 12 MONTHS.] (hiv_interviewer_hivtest_inpastyear)

validValue.meaningText: Date of last test Don't know/Refused
validValue.description: Date of last test Don't know/Refused

question.questionText: HT-6. I'ople have not been tested for HIV. Which of these best describes the most important reason you have not been tested for HIV in the past 12 months? [READ CHOICES. CHOOSE only ONE.] If HT-6 ? 4, go to Say Box before HT-9. (hiv_reasons_not_tested_pastyear)

validValue.meaningText: You think you are at low risk for HIV infection?
validValue.description: You think you are at low risk for HIV infection?

validValue.meaningText: You were afraid of finding out that you had HIV?
validValue.description: You were afraid of finding out that you had HIV?

question.questionText: HT-6a. What was the most important reason you have not been tested for HIV in the past 12 months? Go to Say Box before HT-9. (hiv_mostimportantreason_not_tested_pastyear)
HT-7. Was your test in ___ / ___ [insert date from HT-4] your first positive test? (hiv_mostrecenttest_firstpositive)
HT-7a. When did you first test positive? Month (hiv_when_firsttestpositive_month)
HT-7a. When did you first test positive? Year [77/7777 = Refused, 99/9999 = Don't know] (hiv_when_firsttestpositive_year)
CONF23. INTERVIEWER INSTRUCTIONS: HIV testing was not widely available before 1985. Please confirm the year. Is &[POS1STDY] correct? (hiv_confirm_year_firstpositivetest)

HT-7b. After you tested positive, were you asked by someone from the health department or your health care provider to give the names of your sex or drug use partners so they could be notified that they may have been exposed to HIV? If HT-7b in (0, 7, 9), skip to HT-7d. (hiv_positive_askednotifypartners)
HT-7c.Did you give the names or contact information of any of your partners when asked? (hiv_positive_askednotifypartners_gavenames)

HT-7d. Before your first positive test in ___ / ___ [insert date from HT-4 or HT-7a], did you ever have a negative HIV test? (By negative HIV test, I mean the test showed you did not have HIV infection.] If HT-7d in (0, 7, 9), skip to HT-7e. (hiv_testnegative_before_testpositive)

HT-7d.1 What was the month and year that you got your last negative HIV test? Tell me when you got your last test, not when you got your results. Month [77/7777 = Refused, 99/9999 = Don't know] (hiv_testnegative_before_testpositive_month)

HT-7d.1 What was the month and year that you got your last negative HIV test? Tell me when you got your last test, not when you got your results. Year [77/7777 = Refused, 99/9999 = Don't know] (hiv_testnegative_before_testpositive_year)

HT-7e. In the 2 years before your first positive test in ___ / ___ [insert date from HT-4 or HT-7a], how many times did you get tested for HIV? Don't include your first positive test in that total number. [Refused = 7777, Don't know = 9999] (hiv_2yearsbefore_positivetest_numbertimestested)

HT-7f. Have you ever been seen by a doctor, nurse, or other health care provider for a medical evaluation or care related to your HIV infection? If HT-7f = 1, skip to HT-7g. If HT-7f in (7, 9), skip to Say Box before HT-8b. (hiv_seen_by_doctor)

HT-7f.1. What is the main reason you have never gone to a health care provider for a medical evaluation or care related to your HIV infection? [DO NOT read choices. Chose only ONE reason.] If HT-7f.1 = 8, ask HT-7f.2. Otherwise, skip to Say Box before HT-8b. (hiv_noteverseen_by_doctor_reason)

validValue.description: Feel good, don't need to go

validValue.meaningText: Don't want to think about being HIV-positive/denial
validValue.description: Don't want to think about being HIV-positive/denial

question.questionText: HT-7f.2. Interviewer: Type in other reason Respondent never sought HIV care.Skip to Say Box before HT-8b. (hiv_noteverseen_by_doctor_reasonother)
HT-7g. When did you first go to your health care provider after learning you had HIV? Month (hiv_firstsaw_doctor_afterdiagnosis_month)
HT-7g. When did you first go to your health care provider after learning you had HIV? Year [77/7777 = Refused, 99/9999 = Don't know] (hiv_firstsaw_doctor_afterdiagnosis_year)

INTERVIEWER INSTRUCTIONS: Refer to date of first positive HIV test (HT-4 or HT-7a) If first positive test result was > 3 years before [date of interview], skip to HT-7i. (hiv_interviewer_sawdoctor_confirm)

What is the main reason you didn't go to a health care provider soon after you learned of your HIV infection? [DO NOT read choices. Choose only ONE reason.] If HT-7 = 8, ask HT-7h.1. Otherwise, go to HT-7i. (hiv_notsoonseen_by_doctor_reason)

HT-7i. When did you last go to your health care provider for HIV care? Month (hiv_lastdoctorvisit_hiv_care_month)
HT-7i. When did you last go to your health care provider for HIV care? Year [77/7777 = Refused, 99/9999 = Don't know] (hiv_lastdoctorvisit_hiv_care_year)

HT-7j. What is the main reason you have not gone to health care provider for HIV care in the past 6 months? [DO NOT Read reason types. Choose only ONE reason.] If HT-7j = 8, ask HT-7j.1. Otherwise, go to HT-8. (hiv_notseen_doctor_last6months_reason)

HT-8. Are you currently taking antiretroviral medicines to treat your HIV infection? If HT-8 in (1, 7, 9), skip to Say Box before HT-8b. (hiv_currently_takling_antiretroviral)

HT-8a. What is the main reason you are not currently taking any antiretroviral medicines? [DO NOT read reason types. Choose only ONE reason.] If HT-8a = 9, ask HT-8a.1. Otherwise, go to Say Box before HT-8b. (hiv_notcurrently_takling_antiretroviral_reason)

question.questionText: HT-8a.1 Interviewer: Type in other reason Respondent is not currently taking ARVs: (hiv_notcurrently_takling_antiretroviral_reasonother)
SAY: Researchers are studying whether antiretroviral medicines could possibly be taken to prevent HIV infection. (trtrytrytrt)

HT-8b. Before today, have you ever heard of people who do not have HIV taking antiretroviral medicines, to keep from getting HIV? If HT-8 ? 1 OR HT-8b in (0, 7), go to END of questionnaire. (hiv_heard_taking_antiretroviral_protection)

HT-8c. in the past 12 months, have you given your antiretroviral medicines to a sex partner who was HIV-negative because you thought it might keep them from getting HIV? Go to END of questionnaire. (hiv_given_antiretroviral_to_partner)

module.longName: FOR PARTIICPANTS WHO HAVE NOT PREVIOUSLY TESTED HIV+: SAY: Researchers are studying whether anti-HIV medicine (also called antiretrovirals)--a pill--could possibly be taken to prevent HIV infection.
module.preferredDefinition: FOR PARTIICPANTS WHO HAVE NOT PREVIOUSLY TESTED HIV+: SAY: Researchers are studying whether anti-HIV medicine (also called antiretrovirals)--a pill--could possibly be taken to prevent HIV infection.

question.questionText: HT-9. Before today, have you ever heard of people who do not have HIV taking anti-HIV medicines, to keep from getting HIV? If HT-9 in (0, 7), skip to HT-13. (hiv_heard_taking_antihiv_protection)
HT-10. In the past 12 months, have you taken anti-HIV medicines after sex because you thought it would keep you from getting HIV? (hiv_taken_antihiv_beforesex)

HT-11. In the past 12 months, have you taken anti-HIV medicines before sex because you thought it would keep you from getting HIV? If participant has not taken PEP or PrEP in the past 12 months, go to the END of questionnaire. (hiv_taken_antihiv_aftersex)

HT-12.a. Please tell me if you got any of the anti-HIV medicines you took from the following people or places. Did you get them from.... Doctor or other health care provider (hiv_medicines_from_doctor)

HT-12.b.Please tell me if you got any of the anti-HIV medicines you took from the following people or places. Did you get them from... Sex partner, friend, relative, or acquaintance (hiv_medicines_from_partner)
HT-12.c. Please tell me if you got any of the anti-HIV medicines you took from the following people or places. Did you get them from..... Internet (hiv_medicines_from_internet)
HT-12.d. Please tell me if you got any of the anti-HIV medicines you took from the following people or places. Did you get them from..... Specify (hiv_medicines_from_other)

HT-12.e. Please tell me if you got any of the anti-HIV medicines you took from the following people or places. Did you get them from.......Some other place......... Specify (hiv_medicines_from_otherspecify)
HT-13. Would you be willing to take anti-HIV medicines every day to lower your chances of getting HIV? (hiv_take_medicines_daily)

Editor's Note: The Substance Use Related Co-Morbidities and Health Related Outcomes Specialty Area has slightly modified this protocol from the original protocol text. The Specialty Area removed questions HT14-17 that gauge stigma related to HIV. These items were not critical to our assessment of HIV risk. As a result of removing these questions, some of the skip patterns have been modified to direct the interviewer to the end of the series of questions, instead of going to HT14. (fdgfdghjhjlklk)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The National HIV Behavioral Surveillance System (NHBS) survey began in 2003 to determine risk behavior and HIV testing experiences. NHBS is conducted in cities with a high incidence of AIDS with three groups of people: men who have sex with men (MSM), injection drug users (IDU), and heterosexuals at high risk of exposure to HIV infection. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) provides funding to state and local health departments to collect the information. This is an interviewer-administered protocol that gathers sensitive information.
